titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V.30. Fahrenheit 44 at Sunrise 6.32. Cloudy.

He answered me and said, This present life is not the end where much glory doth abide; therefore have they prayed for the weak. 43. But the day of doom shall be the end of this time, and the beginning of the immortality for to come, wherein corruption is past 2. Esdras 7.42–43.
This passage of the second Apocryphal book of Esdras carries with it internal evidence of its composition since the advent of Christ.

The influenza, better denominated in the French language La grippe has recently become epidemic in this neigbourhood—and has severely exercised several members of my family— It has the last three days been gradually creeping upon me, and at 10 last night I went to bed with a hoarse voice, and a burning sore throat— About one this morning it had become so intense that I was compelled to request my wife to rise and get for me some hot balm tea which she did and sat up with me the whole night, to the imminent danger of her own health. The severity of the stricture upon the throat passed off before morning day-light, and I rose at half past five I rose much relieved but still hoarse, and with the paretytic shaking of the hands totally disabled for writing— I can yet read, and did read four chapters of the second book of Esdras, and took comfort from the verse which I have made out to extract from it at the top of this page— The hope of a future life is the only solace for the infirmities of age, and for all the ills that flesh is heir to, as I am to the condition of an aspen leaf—

I attended meeting as usual morning and afternoon at the Temple. Mr Lunt preached in the forenoon from Galatians 5.6 [“]For in Jesus Christ neither circumcision availeth any thing, nor uncircumcision; but faith which worketh by love”— The whole sum of the Christian Religion is contained in this text— Circumcision was a religious painful and bloody operation upon the body of every male child first instituted by Abraham under the express command of God, for himself and all his descendants but for which no reason was assigned, except that of distinguish them from all the rest of mankind— It was emblematic of nothing but submission against the cry of physical nature itself to the will of God— It is practiced by the posterity of Abraham to the present day— It was abolished not by express command of Jesus Christ, but by the substitution of the rite of baptism in its place, an emblem, of purification from the pollution of nature, and of washing away every impurity from a body born in the image of God, and bound in sympathy to all mankind and to hold a Faith working by love— In the afternoon the Revd. Lemuel Capen
of South Boston, preached from Romans 15.4. a panegyric upon the Scriptures of the old Testament. Mr Capen took tea with us, as also did Mr. Degrand who came out this afternoon from Boston.
2. VI. Fahrenheit 50 at Sunrise 6.33. Cloudy.
That all the earth may be refreshed, and may return, being delivered from thy violence, and that she may hope for the judgment and mercy of him that made her 2. Esdras 11.46.

There is a marked difference between the canonical books of the Bible and the Apocryphal writings in this— I have never met with any difficulty in selecting from four chapters of the old Testament every morning one verse to be copied for the lesson of the day. In these books of Esdras, a sentiment worthy to be imprinted upon the memory and the heart is not always to be found in the compass of four chapters—unless as in the above passage connected with other verbiage which takes away all the point of sententiousness—

I thought myself all day yesterday wholly relieved from the grippe upon my throat—but after going to bed last night, a return in mitigated form of the threatened visit from quinsy—disturbed though it did not entirely destroy my repose— I had sleep but not quiet— Once in the middle of the Night, my wife rose from bed to give me a second cup of warm balm tea, and I dined rise for the day till the entry Clock struck six— The hoarseness had again very much subsided and the sore throat wholly disappeared— My regular course of occupation is broken up, and idleness is the doom of my remaining days by the refusal of my hands to perform the task of recording my daily thoughts and deeds— We had a visit from Miss Susan Tufts of Weymouth this afternoon, and I had a professional visit from Dr Woodward— He prescribed for me a warm foot bath before going to bed this evening—and a tea spoonful of the syrup of Tolu, to be repeated in the course of the Night— He directed me also to wash my legs every morning with a mixture of New-England rum and water— Among my symptoms of decay, is a constant heat and irritation in the outer side of my legs below the calf which I have suffered for the last eighteen months with a discolouring of the parts and feverish heat portending ulceration, and a swelling round the ancles at night whenever I walked in the course of the day. The swelling and the heat generally subsiding in the course of the Night Throughout last winter they were washed with milk and water every night before going to bed, but as the Summer came on the complaint subsided and the fomentation was omitted— With the reapproach of cold weather the complaint has now returned and I am to resort to rum instead of milk to mingle with water for the wash— I received a Letter from Georgiana Cutter of Quincy Illinois 16. October 1846. asking for an answer and a piece of poetry— Mr Charles Sumner declines standing as a candidate for Congress in competition with Robert C. Winthrop—
3. VI. Fahrenheit 54 at Sunrise 6.34. Cloudy. Sunset.
Hear, O ye my beloved, saith the Lord: behold the days of trouble are at hand, but I will deliver you from the same. 75. Be ye not afraid neither doubt, for God is your guide. 2. Esdras 16.74.75.

The days of trouble are at hand—and for deliverance from them God must be our guide— The last of our deliverances, must be a release from the burdens and sufferings of life, and our last reliance, resignation to his will.

Dr Woodward’s warm foot bath, and his two teaspoon fulls of Syrup of Tolu were succeeded by a quiet night, and sleep till near six this morning when I rose— Besides my usual frictions and ablutions, I washed my legs with New England rum and water, mixed about half and half— The teazing titillation with which they are unceasingly tormented was less annoying through the day than it has been for months, but I may not hope for a long respite from this remedy. The mildness of the weather doubtless contributed to my momentary relief— My sore throat is gone— The hoarseness of my voice much mollified—but the shaking hand cannot be made steady and my efforts to write are vain— We had a morning visit from Ex President Quincy—who has removed to Boston for the Winter, but still lingers about the Quincy hive— And I received a letter from his Son Edmund Quincy—Dedham 2. Novr 1846. informing me that the Norfolk County Anti-Slavery Society will hold a quarterly meeting in the Town Hall in Quincy on Wednesday and Thursday of this week, beginning on Wednesday afternoon and continuing through the next day and evening: and inviting my attendance at the Meeting. I took to the Post Office this afternoon my Letter to Mrs. Maria Weston Chapman with my contribution for the Liberty-Bell— I received also and read pamphlet Memoir of the Megatherium and other extinct gigantic quadrupeds on the Coast of Georgia, with observations on its Geologic features by William B. Hodgson— It consists of several distinct essays—first on the fossil remains of Georgia— The Origin and progress of their discovery— The Geography and Geologic features of the fossil region— A memorandum by Dr Joseph Habersham of Savannah of the most important fossil bones and shells in his possession, discovered in 1842 on the Island of Skiddaway on the Sea coast of Georgia— The papers affirm the discovery of the remains of several distinct animals of enormous dimensions—Megatherium—Megatonyx—Mastodon—Horse—Hog-hippopotamos, Elephant and bos. These are all considered by the author as the enduring records of the antiquity of the globe— As the medals and the vestiges of creation, by which its pre human history is read, and which attest the rise and fall of kingdoms animal, before the existence of Man— This is a hasty and unwarranted conclusion— The existence of a race of Giants is expressly recognized in holy writ—but not before the creation of man—
4. V. Fahrenheit 58 at Sunrise 6.36. Sunset 4.50.
Ask counsel of all that are wise, and despise not any counsel that is profitable— Tobit 4.18.

This is good advice— The two books of Esdras are not either in my French or my German Bible— They were not admitted into the Canon of Scripture at the Council of Trent, and are not considered as Canonical by the Church of Rome. The books canonized by the Council of Trent are Tobit, Judith, Wisdom, Ecclesiasticus, and first and second Maccabes—and Baruch, annexing it to Jeremiah— The sixth of the 39 Articles of the Church of England after declaring canonical 38 books of the old Testament, says “and the other books (as Hierome saith) the Church doth read for example of life, and instruction of manners; but yet doth it not apply there to establish any doctrine: these are the first and second, called the third and fourth Books of Esdras, Tobias, Judith, the rest of the Book of Hester, Wisdom, Jesus the son of Sirach, Baruch the prophet, The Song of the three children, The story of Susanna, Of Bel and the Dragon, The Prayer of Manassas, and the first and second book of Maccabees[”]— The Protestant churches in general, save the church of England deny all authority whatever to all the apocryphal books, and they are never read in any of the congregational churches of New England— I once heard Dr Frothingham however, take a text from one of them—auxiliary to another text from the New Testament— I read them in company with the true Bible, but with a different feeling for their -structions than for those of the canonical books The Book of Jesus the Son of Sirach, Ecclesiasticus; is the only one of the collection upon which I set much value, and that is inestimable— The Count de Maistre at Saint Petersbourg spoke to me in rapturous terms of the Wisdom of Solomon, and I have often heard it highly prized by others— There are in it many good sentiments in it but I do not concur in the judgment which dignifies it with the name of Solomon. The books of the Maccabees, are readable only as historical narratives, and as such are exceedingly confused— This book of Tobit is a sort of fairy tale, remarkable chiefly as an interesting picture of domestic life and of the family affections among the Jews, and of their attachment to their religion during the Assyrian captivity.

Mrs Charles and Mary Louisa went to Boston in the Carriage, but returned to dinner. There was a steady and soaking rain all the morning which cleared off towards night— The weather confined me to the house, and I forgot the invitation of Mr Edmund Quincy to the meeting of the Norfolk County Anti-Slavery Society held at the Town-Hall— It was my intention to have attended— I have no communion with any Anti-Slavery Society, and they have disclaimed all confidence in me: but I sympathize with all their aversion to Slavery—
5. IV. Fahrenheit 36 at Sunrise—6.38. Cloudy clear. Sunset 4–49—

And as he went he remembered the words of Raphael, and took the ashes of the perfumes. and put the heart and the liver of the fish thereupon and made a smoke therewith 3— Tho which smell, when the evil spirit had smelled, he fled into the utmost parts of Egypt, and the angel bound him.
Tobit 8.2–3.

In the fourth Book of Milton’s Paradise there is introduced a very strange comparison founded upon this passage of the book of Tobit.— After an enchanting description of the beauties of Paradise, and especially of the fragrance of its flowers, as enjoyed by Satan upon his approach to the garden of Eden, on his mischievous mission from Pandemonium, to express the delight administered to the senses of the fallen angel by these balmy essences he compares them to the exquisite perfumes of Araby the blest, pervading the atmosphere far out at Sea, and breathed by Navigators round the Cape of Hope, he adds

lg.l: So entertained those odorous sweets the Fiend,
Who came their bane; though with them better pleas’d
Than Asmodëus with the fishy fume
That drove him though enamour’d, from the spouse
Of Tobit’s son, and with a vengeance sent
From Media post to Egypt, there fast bound.

div.p: Paradise Lost 4.166.
What a transition from the sublime to the ridiculous.

The Revd. Mr Connell paid us again an afternoon visit— I have formed from this slight acquaintance a very favourable opinion of his character— I invited him to stay and pass the night with us, but he declined— I went with him to the Rail-road depot for the train of 5. p.m. and met there my Son going in to the independent rally meeting of the whigs who have nominated Dr Howe as a candidate for Congress in opposition to Robert C. Winthrop— As the Cars departed I went to my Son’s house where I found Edmund Quincy there— The Norfolk County Anti-Slavery Meeting had been held, at the Lyceum Hall under the Town house and had adjourned to half past seven this evening— We staid with Mr Charles till after tea—and I went with Mr Quincy to the Lyceum Hall where the Anti-Slavery Society were reassembled— Wendell Phillips was addressing them in an eloquent speech— He spoke for upwards of an hour longer; and was followed for about another hour by Edmund Quincy—and him followed Parker Pilsbury an Orator with whom I had not been before acquainted— The question was then taken upon certain Resolutions which had been offered and they were adopted with one dissenting voice, but they were not read— The meeting was then adjourned without day— The Lyceum Hall was well filled with an attentive auditory, more than half of which were women. I walked home, Mrs Charles was gone up the hill. She got home about 11.
6. IV.15. Fahrenheit 34. at Sunrise 6.39.
Prayer is good, with fasting, and alms, and righteousness— A little with righteousness is better than much with unrighteousness. It is better to give alms than to lay up gold— Tobit 12.8.

Prayer, fasting, alms—righteousness—constitute the moral code of the Apocryphal books— Tobit and his family were of the tribe of Naphthali, one of the ten, and consequently of the Assyrian Captivity. He lived at Ninive, and his family and tribe fell into idolatry, and sacrificed unto the heifer Baal—but Tobit himself adhered to the exclusive worship at Jerusalem— The marriage of his son Tobias with Sara, daughter of Raguel who dwelt at Ecbatana, a city of Media, was contracted conformably to the Levitical law, like that of Boaz with Ruth, as the nearest of kin— And Tobit had committed ten Talents in deposit to Gabael, in Rages, another city of Media. By a marvelous accident he had become blind and Sara was bewitched by an evil Spirit named Asmodeus who had fallen in love with her, and had killed seven husbands to whom she had been successively been betrothed on their respective wedding nights— So Tobit prays at Ninive for restoration of his sight, and Sara prays at Ecbatana, for deliverance from the witchery of Asmodeus—and Raphael was sent to heal them both—to scale away the whiteness of Tobit’s eyes, and to give Sara for a wife to Tobias and to bind Asmodeus the evil spirit—all which he performs— Tobit lives after all this nearly a hundred years at Ninive— Towards the close of his life he called his son Tobias and strictly enjoined upon him and his six Sons to remove from Ninive to Ecbatana in Media, because the prophesy of Jonas against Ninive should surely come to pass and Ninive should be destroyed— Tobit seems not to have known that when Jonah did prophesy the destruction of Ninive, it was to be consummated within 40 days; but that the people of Ninive repented of their Sins, and God repented of the evil that he had said that he would do unto them: and he did it not the prophesy was never fulfilled; to the great affliction and indignation of the prophet himself—

I had morning calls successively from Revd. E. Whitney corresponding Secretary of a Boston Society for the promotion of moral reform, for which he solited a contribution— He had a duodecimo volume entitled the Sabbath, by Revd. A. A. Phelps. 3d. Edition 1844. I took the book for half a dollar, but declined the contribution—and from Revd. Austin Dickinson, with written recommendations from Theodore Frelinghuysen at New-York in May and Samuel Hubbard at Boston in July— He too solicited a contribution for him to circulate religious articles in the popular Newspapers, which I declined— In the afternoon I had visits from Dr Duggan and E. G. Robinson, publisher of the Norfolk County Democrat.
7. V. Fahrenheit 35 at Sunrise 6.40. Sunset 4–46—
But before his death he heard of the destruction of Ninive, which was taken by Nabuchodonosor and Assuerus, and before he died he rejoiced over Ninive. Tobit 14.15—

In the book of Jonah, God says there were in the City of Ninive six score thousand persons who knew not their right hand from their left, importing a population of a million—besides much cattle— He says this in answer to the reproach of Jonah, for his forbearance to execute the threat of destruction which Jonah by his command had announced to the inhabitants of that city— The multitude of human beings who must suffer by the destruction of such a city besides other living animals is presented as a motive for the Lord to revoke his own decree against the devoted victim of his anger, and shews in bold relief the absurd inconsistency of the prophet who had bowels of compassion for a withering vegetable, and none for the city of Ninive— Here the book of Jonah closes, and leaves a delightful sentiment for the memory to impress upon the heart— The close of the book of Tobit has an effect directly the reverse upon mine— Tobias lives to hear of the destruction of Ninive, and rejoices over it— Here is the Spirit of Jonah, and not the Spirit of God—

I walked round the Railway square, but the sight of the rising Sun was intercepted by clouds and the railway bridge was powdered with white frost— My wife went into Boston with Mrs Charles to prepare her town house and Mary Louisa for a riding lesson— They returned home to dine— My brother Charles’s daughter, widow Susan Boylston Treadway resides at Richmond Virginia with her only daughter Susan, wife of Adoniram Judson Crane, a lawyer in that city. Her circumstances are narrow, and she has undertaken to keep a boarding house— I have received a Letter from her asking a loan upon interest for 12 months to assist her in furnishing her house— I answered her Letter this day, enclosing an order from the merchants Bank Boston upon the Bank of Virginia, Richmond for 200 dollars, payable to the order of my Son, Charles Francis Adams, and by him endorsed payable to the order of Mrs Treadway—and a promissory note for her to date and sign and return by mail to me at Boston, to be paid in 12 months, but not upon interest— I have also received a Letter from Wesley Carlin Secretary of a Committee of certain inhabitants of the County of Alexandria late in the District of Columbia, opposed to the retrocession of that County to the State of Virginia. They ask my opinion of the constitutionality of that act, and also as to the probability of success if they should bring the subject before the Supreme Court— I have no doubt that the act is unconstitutional, but I have no confidence in the success of an appeal to the Supreme Court— The balance of Justice in that tribunal is loaded with the weight of Slavery—
8. IV.15 Fahrenheit 35. at Sunrise 6.42. Circle round the moon.

And in the eighteenth year, the two and twentieth day of the first month, there was talk in the house of Nabuchodonosor king of the Assyrians, that he should, as he said, avenge himself on all the earth.
Judith 2.1.

This Nabuchodonosor, called in the Hebrew Bible Nebuchadnezzar, and Nebuchadrezzar, is not known by that name in prophane history—nor is the person named Nabuchodonosor in this book of Judith the same with the one who put out the eyes of Zedekiah and extinguished the kingdom of Judah by the Babylonian captivity— The heathen name of this Nabuchodonosor was Saosduchinus—his Capitol was Niniveh, and what or where this Bethulia was, which his General Holofernes was besieging when Judith delivered her country and the world from him in this wonderful manner no one knows— The name of the dreamer Nabuchodonosor whose dreams Daniel discovered and expounded was Nabopolassar, and he was the father of Nebuchadnezzar the great— I cannot disentangle the snarl.

Mr Lunt preached this morning at the Temple, from Acts 1.8. the last clause of the verse—“and ye shall be witnesses unto me both in Jerusalem, and in all Judea, and in Samaria, and unto the uttermost part of the earth.” He omitted the first clause—“But ye shall receive power, after that the Holy Ghost is come upon you.” These were the last words spoken by Jesus to his apostles, after his passion, on mount Olivet— They consist first of the promise of power, by the outpouring of the holy Ghost—and 2. of the instruction to go and preach as his witnesses, throughout the earth— Mr Lunt did not remark upon the grant of power nor upon the promise of the holy Ghost; but confined his discourse to the character of witnesses, which was conferred upon the apostles— The greek word is martyrs—ye shall be martyrs unto me.— The occurrence, and the last words of Jesus are related somewhat differently, in the last three verses of the gospel of Matthew—but the drift of Mr Lunt’s discourse was upon the import of the word witnesses applicable only to facts— His argument was that the truth of the Christian Religion depended not upon the nature of its doctrine, nor upon the faith or belief of its followers, but upon the facts of its history of which the apostles could be preachers to the world, efficient only so far as they were faithful witnesses to facts— Mr Lunt’s afternoon Sermon was from James 1.19—[“]Wherefore, my beloved brethren, let every man be swift to hear, slow to speak, slow to wrath” an admirable lesson of practical morality; from which he took occasion to bear testimony against Slavery, and to express the hope that no Slaveholder would ever hereafter be elected the chief magistracy of this Union— This doctrine is not yet sufficiently palatable even for this climate— Charles and his wife spent the evening here—
9. IV. Fahrenheit 46 at Sunrise 6.43. Cloudy Sunset 4.44.

For thy power standeth not in multitude, nor thy might in strong men: for thou art a God of the afflicted, an helper of the oppressed, an upholder of the weak, a protector of the forlorn, a saviour of them that are without hope— Judith 9–11—

This is a part of the prayer of Judith, before setting out upon her expedition to visit Holofernes— Perhaps it is the best part of that prayer— The allusion to the atchievement of her ancestor Simeon to avenge the dishonour of his Sister Dinah is not in the same Spirit—for Jacob the father of Simeon pronounced a terrible anathema upon that exploit of his Sons Simeon and Levi— But there is nothing in the inspired Scriptures themselves, that gives a more exalted and endearing idea of the creator and governor of the world than the attributes ascribed to him in this part of the prayer—

A black man by the name of Nathaniel Groom, came this morning, soliciting a contribution to enable him to purchase the freedom of his wife a Slave at New Orleans, and of whom the price is seven hundred dollars— He had a certificate recommendatory from John G. Palfrey 9. August 1846. and a subscription book with numerous underwritten names, to which I added my own. 3. This was the general election day for Governor and Lieutenant Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, Senators for the Counties and Representatives for the towns in the State Legislature for the year 1847. and members of the Districts for the 30th. Congress of the United States. About noon I walked to the town house and voted for the regular whig ticket, on a printed paper, after taking off from it my own name as Representative to Congress, 8th District— There were very few persons in the hall, and no excitement— The vote taken was little more in numbers than half the vote taken in November 1844— The weather was foul— Rain great part of the day and evening— There was a separate town meeting, at which a Committee of 7. George Newcomb chairman was chosen, to consider if the town will undertake to erect the building for an Academy or Classical School as proposed in my fathers donation to the town; and also provide an apartment in the Town-house for the Library which still remains in my farm house— The Committee are to procure a plan for the building and estimates of the cost of erecting it, and report the same to the town at a meeting to be called for that purpose. Mr Thomas Greenleaf President of the Supervisors of the Temple and School fund, returning from the Town hall, called, and informed me of these votes. I met Mr George Newcomb at the Hall and he came this afternoon to my house—and we agreed that the Committee should procure a plan for the school house and estimates of the cost and he should concert with Mr Greenleaf for a meeting of the Committee and the Supervisors of the time of which he will give me notice.
10. IV. Fahrenheit 46 at Sunrise 6.44— Fog. Rain. Sunset 4.43
These slaves have dealt treacherously; one woman of the Hebrews hath brought shame upon the house of king Nabuchodonosor; for behold, Holofernes lieth upon the ground without a head—
Judith 14.18

This day had been fixed by my Son and his wife for their removal with their family to Boston for the winter— But the foul weather continued all last night and this day and they postponed their departure till to morrow— Elizabeth C. Adams, and her brother John Quincy were here and Elizabeth remained till the Evening— My Sons daughter Louisa, and his Son John Quincy are already fixed at Boston since last Saturday Louisa at the school kept by Mr Emerson, and John at the Latin town School. At the town Hall yesterday one of the distributors of votes gave me a printed paper as follows—

list.item:
For Governor
George N. Briggs
of Pittsfield—

For Lieutenant Governor
John Reed
of Yarmouth

For Representative to Congress. 8th District
John Quincy Adams
of Quincy

For Town Representative
Charles Clapp. This name in manuscript.

div.p: This ticket after taking off my own name and pinning together the two parts of the paper bearing the other names— I deposited with my own hand in the ballot box held out to me by one of the Selectmen. This was my vote— No other ticket was presented to me—but there were at least two others— The Democratic ticket and the Liberty party ticket. My competitors as in 1844 wereWright of Roxbury on the democratic ticket, and Appleton Howe of Weymouth on the Liberty party ticket— What the returns are I know not— Governor Briggs has in Boston a majority of more than 3000. and R. C. Winthrop a majority upwards of 2600— The whigs have sweeping majorities all over the State. Charles and his wife spent the evening here.
11. IV. Fahrenheit 48. at Sunrise 6.46. Cloud. Sunset 4.42
And there was none that made the children of Israel any more afraid in the days of Judith, nor a long time after her death—
Judith 16.25.

It is passing strange that there should be no trace of this War of the king of Assyria Nabuchodonosor against the kingdom of Israel, in which Holofernes was the chief commander, nor of the siege of Bethulia, nor of the person of Judith, either in the Books of Kings or of Chronicles—

Shalmaneser king of Assyria carried into captivity Hoshea the last king of Samaria 721 years before Christ— Sennacherib invaded Judea in 714. and in 710. The angel of the Lord slew 185000 Assyrians in one Night. Sennacherib went home to Nineveh, was murdered by two of his own sons, and was succeeded by another of his sons Esarhaddon.

One hundred years after this, the reigns of Hezekiah—Manasses—Amon and Josiah kings of Judah having intervened, and Josiah having been slain in War with Pharaoh Necho king of Egypt, who made Eliakim a son of Josiah king and changed his name to Jehoiakim—in 610—Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon first appears subdues and takes Jehoiachim to Babylon, and makes Mattaniah whom he calls Zedekiah king of Judah— In 599. Zedekiah rebels and in 588. the Temple is burnt—the City of Jerusalem destroyed. Zedekiah taken carried to Babylon his children slain before his eyes, and his eyes then put out— It is impossible to account consistently with all this for a Nabuchodonosor king of Assyria, whose commanding general Holofernes is slain by the widow Judith, and whose army is defeated and expelled so that the children of Israel had none to make them afraid during the life of Judith and for a long time after.

My Son, with his wife and family removed to Boston for the winter; and our Cook Mrs Bridget Broderick and her daughter Mary Ann left us— My wife had intended to depart with Mrs John Adams and our Grand daughter Mary-Louisa for Washington, but the continued North-easterly storm has induced her to postpone the commencement of her journey till next Monday— Mr Clarke landlord of the United States Hotel Boston, came with Mr Howard of Springfield came to enquire concerning a title to Lands in Nova-Scotia— I called after dinner at the Office of the Quincy Patriot, but the publisher John A Green was not there— I paid a visit also to Mr and Mrs Lunt, whose new built house on the hill is not yet quite ready to receive them— Our evening was dreary for the loss of the company of our children from the hill—
12. IV. Fahrenheit 48 at Sunrise 6.47. Rain flood. Sunset 4.41
In the second year of the reign of Artaxerxes the great, in the first day of the month Nisan, Mardocheus the son of Jairus, the son of Semei the son of Cisai, of the tribe of Benjamin, had a dream.
Rest of Esther 11–2.

In the Hebrew and English Bibles, in the Book of Esther this king of the Medes and Persians is called Ahasuerus, with a parenthesis (this is Ahasuerus which reigned from India even unto Ethiopia, over an hundred and seven and twenty provinces) and sat on the throne of his kingdom in Shushan the palace— In the Septuagint Bible he is called Artaxerxes— Usher supposes him to have been Darius the son of Hystaspes, Prideaux, Artaxerxes Longimanus—Scaliger Xerxes—why he is called Ahasuerus, no one pretends to explain— It was about the first return of the Jews from Babylon, and the rebuilding of the Temple— Mordecai and Esther were of the tribe of Benjamin, and he had been carried with Jeconiah or Jehoiakim to the Babylonian captivity by Nebuchadnezzar.

The storm continues without abatement— Mr Jonathan Wilde of Braintree was here again but I could give him no further information concerning the condition of the pension claim of his mother Deborah Wilde, at Washington— I promised him to pay particular attention to it on my return to it for the approaching Session of Congress. Mr Thayer nephew of Minott Thayer was here and brought me a Letter from him stating that on the Saturday before I left home for Cincinnati—that is 21. October 1843. he and Asa French, and Mr Fogg, came and returned to me the volume copy of the old Braintree Records which they had borrowed upwards of two years before— I turned to my Diary of that day, and found the statement fully confirmed—yet I had wholly forgotten the fact— I received Letters from Henry B. Wheelwright and J. N. Brewer, dated yesterday at Roxbury, advising me of an error in the election returns from Roxbury of the election for a Representative in Congress for the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, held last Monday and published in the Boston Atlas of Tuesday morning— The error consisted in setting down 791 votes for me, and 554 for other candidates, leaving a majority of only 237. in my favour— The real vote was 992 for me, and 341 for others, leaving a majority for me of 651— I answered these Letters thanking the writers for their information and for the interest they have taken in having the error corrected. I received also a Letter from George C. Beckwith corresponding Secretary of the American Peace Society Boston 9. Novr 1846. The weather confined me to the house all day, excepting a walk round the railway square between dinner and dark.
13. IV. Fahrenheit 44 at Sunrise 6.48 Storm. Sunset— 4–40.
For honourable age is not that which standeth in length of time, nor that is measured by number of years. 9. But wisdom in the gray hair unto man, and an unspotted life is old age—
Wisdom of Solomon 4.8.9.
This sentiment thus expressed is worthy of the Wisdom of Solomon, but partakes rather of train of thought of the Gentile philosophers than of the Hebrew Moralists—

The Northeast Storm confined me still to the house with the exception of a walk after dinner round the Railway square. My Son came out from Boston and dined with us and returned after dinner— The Letter received yesterday from the Secretary of the American Peace Society Beckwith states the wish of that Society to offer as large a premium as can be procured for a Review of the War with Mexico, in its Origin, its Progress, and its Results, pecuniary political and moral— Their object being to bring this iniquitous War, under the permanent ban? of public opinion and thus make it an effectual warning against future wars of a like character.— The Society solicit an expression of my views as to the measure itself and the best means of carrying it into effect. This Letter requires a cool, deliberate and unequivocal answer, and one which unassisted I cannot give— I believe it however my duty to make the attempt and my time is now so short, and my labour so slow, that I almost despair of effecting it— This journal absorbs the whole of my time in the struggle to continue the record of a daily page which I have more than once renounced as utterly impracticable— I have also become entangled in researches of Bible Chronology— The English Universal History begins with the Chronology of the book of Genesis from the creation to the birth of Abraham—and commences the general history of the world with Egypt— Rollin commences with the Assyrians, Lydians, Medes, Persians and Greeks— I consult the Tablettes Chronologiques of Lenglet Dufresnoy— The tables in the 20th. volume of the French Dictionaire Historique 9th. edition 1812— Josephus, Herodotus, Diodorus Siculus, and find no end, in wandering mazes lost— I have received a Letter from Mrs Rebeca Boylston Drury 6. Novr 1846 West Cambridge, claiming kindred with the Boylston blood, her mother having been a daughter of Richard Boylston of Charlestown. She says she has a genealogical table of the family from the time of their migration to this Country down to a recent date— I presume a copy of that possessed by Mr Peter C. Brooks.

And if a man love righteousness, her labours are virtues; for she teacheth temperance, and prudence, justice and fortitude; which are such things as men can have nothing more profitable in their life.
Wisdom of Solomon 8.7.

Here is another admirable sentiment, but which did not originate with Solomon— It comes from the moral philosophy of the Grecian Schools— I wasted hours this day in searching to trace it to its source, with no better success than to find them named in Cicero’s Treatise de Inventione 2.53. I believe the word Virtue is not once used in the Old Testament— In the new Testament it is used in two very different senses—1. Mark 5.30 and Luke 6.19. where the diseased were healed by touching the hem of the garment of Jesus, and it is said virtue went out of him; but in both these instances the word in the Greek Testament is δύναμις—power—and 2.2. Peter 1.3 and 5 where the word in the Greek Testament is ἀρετῆ— The word virtus in Latin, and by its derivation means manhood, because, as Cicero says Fortitude is one of the properties of man and being the chief Virtues is taken to include them all under the name of virtus—manhood— In Johnson’s dictionary there are ten different significations affixed to the word virtue— Its general meaning is a compound of all that is commendable in man— But this general excellence consists of many distinct properties some of them conflicting with others—hence the four cardinal virtues of the Greeks and Romans—and they are here called the labours of righteousness But when St. Peter exhorts the disciples of Christ to add to their faith virtue; and to their virtue knowledge and to their knowledge five other good moral qualities the sense of the word virtue is not well defined; for if virtue is added to faith and knowledge an imperfect enumeration of separate virtues is worse than superfluous— Tis Pope’s order to a Tailor for a suit of clothes and a pair of breeches— The storm continues— Charles’s son John Quincy came out from Boston, and dined with us and returned— I received a Letter from George Newcomb with a copy of the resolution adopted at the Quincy Town Meeting last Monday relating to the building of an Academy— The Committee of seven appointed to confer and to act in conjunction with the Supervisors of the Adams School fund are George Newcomb, William B. Duggan, Dr Orange Clark, Israel W. Munroe William D. Gray, Manning W. Sullivan, and Lysander Richards— The same Committee are to take order for the removal of the library. Mr Newcomb notifies a joint meeting of the Committee and the Supervisors for next Friday the 20th. instt. at 10 O’Clock A.M. in the Selectmen’s room of the town Hall— I received also the pamphlet Bible Society Record N. 19 November 1846. and Redwood Fisher’s National Magazine and Industrial Record—November 1846. Vol 3. N. 6. but I can find no time to read it—

Forsomuch then as thou art righteous thyself, thou orderest all things righteously; thinking it not agreeable with thy power to condemn him that hath not deserved to be punished.
Wisdom of Solomon 12.15.

There is in this passage a good principle of moral instruction for the rulers of men, but it is not altogether correct as applied to the dispensations of Providence— For whom the Lord loveth he chasteneth and scourgeth every son whom he receiveth— Hebrews 12.6.

Mr Lunt preached at the Temple, in the forenoon from Luke 5.16—[“]And he with drew himself into the wilderness and prayed” The discourse was upon the duty of prayer, and the example of Jesus was urged in this case as the more impressive, in as much as his retirement into the wilderness to pray was immediately after the miraculous draught of fishes, and precisely at the time when he cured a man of leprosy, by merely touching him and saying I will, be thou clean, in answer to the leper, who fell on his face and besought him saying Lord, if thou wilt thou canst make me clean— This example seems to be a special recommendation of solitary prayer, as that which is commonly called the Lord’s prayer is in form and substance a social prayer.— What he prayed for in the wilderness the book does not say— The Lord’s prayer is a form of daily supplication suited to the whole human race, as children to their common parent, and after uttering the aspiration of the Soul that the kingdom of God may come and his will be done on Earth as in heaven, prays first for a daily food, and next for conditional forgiveness of sins. But this is not the prayer, to offer which Jesus withdrew into the wilderness, what was it? If he was himself a person of the triune God, to whom did he pray? and if he had power to heal leprosy with a word and to forgive sins, for what did he pray?— After the morning service Mr Lunt read the proclamation of Governor George N. Briggs for the annual thanksgiving on Thursday The 26th. of this month—and he gave notice that in the afternoon there would be a special service on occasion of closing the Sunday school for the Season— It consisted of the singing of three occasional hymns on a printed page, distributed in the pews—the children of the school being present to the number of near 150, and joining in the song— The sermon was from Ecclesiastes 11.6. “In the morning sow thy seed.” and was in the nature of an Address specially to the children— There was in this discourse, and also in the Governors proclamation for Thanksgiving a slap at Slavery—

For the hope of the unthankful shall melt away as the winter’s hoar frost, and shall run away as unprofitable water—
Wisdom of Solomon 16.29.

My wife had intended to depart with the family this morning for Washington; but the storm is not yet exhausted— It rain all the morning, and when it held up continued dark and cloudy till night— The journey was postponed Mr White was elected last Monday Representative for the town of Braintree to the Legislature of the Commonwealth for the year 1847. Mr Clapp was the whig Candidate for the same office for the town of Quincy and received 210 votes—but 222 were necessary for a choice and he fell short ten votes— On the 29th. of last August Mr White called on me and stated that he proposed to address to the Postmaster General a charge against Fisher Ames Kingsbury Postmaster at Weymouth of writing anonymous Letters to him and exacting the payment of postage upon them. He now said that he had addressed a complaint to that effect to the Postmaster general from whom he had not received any answer—and he asked my advice what he should do. I advised him to wait till I should go to Washington at the beginning of the next Month— That on arriving there I would see the Postmaster General and urge him to institute an enquiry and examination into the official conduct of Mr Kingsbury—as I believed he would and Mr White would have ample opportunity to substantiate his charge— Mr White exhibited to me several of these anonymous, libellous papers, and one palpable forgery. One was a printed advertisement offering 20 dollars reward for the discoverer who had purloined a Letter from the Post-Office, and 10 dollars for the Letter— One of these printed advertisements was posted upon the door of Mr Whites Office and attached to it a paper, on which was written “And Nathan said unto David, Thou art the man[”]— He shewed me several of the anonymous Letters, and one a plain forgery signed by the name of a Miss Raymond of Bridgwater, and all, as Mr White is well assured written by Kingsbury himself or by a tool of his, a worthless man named Pratt— I asked Mr White what could possibly be the motive of Kingsbury for such conduct. He said he did not know and could not imagine— That he and Kingsbury were both practising lawyers, and Kingsbury had begun with him by professions of friendship and mutual good offices but had first played him a shabby trick in business, and now for the last three years had been a continual annoyance to him by these offensive anonymous letters and infamous imputations— Mr Clapp was here about two hours, and Mr White not less than four—

For in all things, O Lord, thou didst magnify thy people, and glorify them, neither didst thou highly regard them; but didst assist them in every time and place Wisdom of Solomon 19.22

The closing verse of this Apocryphal book, and in the estimation of many pious Christians the best of them—though in mine much inferior to that which follows the wisdom of Jesus the son of Sirach or Ecclesiasticus.
On rising this morning I found the sky had cleared off and I saw the thin strip of the moon, the last day before the change—

At a quarter before eight O’Clock this morning with Mrs John Adams, her daughter Mary Louisa, Margaret Dulany, and our Coachman Albert Putnam, departed in the train of Cars of the old Colony Railroad to Boston, where my Son was waiting for them and at half-past eight they all started by the Long-Island Rail-road for New-York, my wife and family, on their way to Washington, and my son bearing them company to New-York, and perhaps to Philadelphia— I remained for the morning at Quincy settling accounts and packing up for departure. A man came out from Bigelow’s livery-stable to take our Carriage, and a pair of horses into Boston— I called at Mr Beale’s and desired him to give notice to Mr George Newcomb and Mr Thomas Greenleaf, that my son being gone to New-York and expecting not to return before next Saturday, the joint meeting of the town of Quincy’s committee, and the supervisors of the Temple and school fund, proposed to be held at the town hall next Friday must be postpon’d and that I proposed to substitute next Tuesday the 24th. for the meeting, to which Mr Beale agreed— After dinner at 4. O’Clock—I came in our Carriage with Miss Smith into Boston, and leaving her at Mr James H. Foster’s in Bedford Street where she resides in Winter, with her Sister Mrs Foster I came to my Son’s house, Number 57. Mount Vernon Street, where I found his wife and five children, all well— My Son was gone with his mother— Here as has become a sort of annual custom I propose to pass the remainder of this month— Mrs Frothingham, and her son Thomas were here part of this Evening— The Doctor is on a visit at New-York—
